description: I keep coming back for the excellent bahn mi sandwiches. The crispy tofu uses veganaise not mayonnaise so it's totally vegan. I get extra jalapeños on my grilled pork sandwich and I always get one to go - they heat up well in the oven the next day. Perfect combo of tasty meats, fresh veggies and crispy roll keep me coming back. If your on the road or in a hurry, call ahead and they'll have your order ready.
author: John K.

description:
The secret to good Vietnamese Bahn Mi is the bread, and this one is thicker and heavier. Still baguette but it is not hollow inside.

I had chicken with lemon grass - okay. 
Girlfriend ordered shaken beef - much better!
author: Anelya S.

description: This place used to be good. I've been going here since they opened. I probably buy 2-4 sammies a month. Since the new owner or management, the meat portion has gotten smaller and smaller. They barley use any daikon. A total disappointment.
author: Lilia R.

description: I have come here before and their banh mi are pretty good, but last night we had some and they made us very sick. Never going back after that!
author: Sarah I.

description: The crispy tofu sandwich was totally fine, I'd probably go back at some point if I'm in the area again. The people working here are really nice. And under $8 for a sandwich felt quite reasonable for sf.
author: Nina J.

description:
This place is the best. Getting here was a bit difficult because we had to go downstairs and I don't think there were clear signs showing us the way.

I came here a few times and ordered the pork viet sandwich because it's my all-time favorite. I feel like I'm a bad judge of these sandwiches because they tend to taste very similar to me. I guess I'll spot a bad one when I spit it out. 

They also have some Asian snacks too, which is somewhat random but it's Asian so I guess it still fits.
author: Juliana P.

description:
I was hesitant at first. What kind of Vietnamese sandwich place is named Dinosaurs? There's not even an explanation. You'd think this is some hip, new, fusion bullshit, but that's not it at all. They keep it simple and tasty. Looking at the menu, you'd probably think this was a pricey Vietnamese sandwich. But considering all other lunch and dinner options, a $5 sandwich is a great deal. And these sandwiches are loaded quite nicely.

The special is what you'd expect, roasted pork, pate, cha lua, do chua, cilantro, and jalepeno in a crunchy french roll. They also have grilled chicken, pork, beef, and have you. On top of that, they have tofu and mushroom options as well. Same goes for the spring rolls. They have the more traditional shredded pork and shrimp, and chicken and shrimp. Then there's the veggie-friendly option, taro and tofu. I'm also a fan of their salads: shrimp papaya and chicken cabbage. They're a tad on the small side, but a nice refreshing alternative. I've probably tried most things on the menu and there isn't really anything un-tasty here.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I discovered your other location in the Castro today. Your address is a bit confusing. Can you make 16th Street the address? The signage from Market Street was hidden behind other signs. Keep up the yummy sandwiches and I'll be visiting again soon.
author: Judy M.

description:
Not the most authentic Vietnamese sandwich in the city but it's ....I'd say...doable. I first discovered Dinosaurs in 2012, back when their sandwiches started off at $4.75. I work about 2 blocks away and used to come here all the time for lunch. Until their prices drastically increased I slowly stopped coming here. Now for an $8 banh mi, it's way too pricey. Therefore I'm giving 1 star for price increase but 4 stars for the sandwich. Reason being, I love the fact that they are very generous with the meat and veggies. It always feels like a heavy log each time I pick up my order. I always get "the Special". It's loaded with pork and pate. My favorite out of all. Bread can be very hard so it hurts my jaws trying to bite into it. Their Vietnamese coffee doesn't taste like it's freshly brewed. Almost tasted like a day old coffee. No bueno. 

Service is good. I really like the lady with the short pixie hair. Always put on a smile and very friendly.

TIPS: *Be sure to check in on FB or Yelp so you can get 10% off on your meal.
*IG your Dinosaurs meal and you'll get a free small fountain drink.
*Call ahead if you don't want to wait in line.
*If you want less carbs, tell them to take the inside breading out and add more veggies. No extra charge!
author: Cathy P.

description:
I hate being wrong. Fortunately, it doesn't happen very often.

Something about the location and the name of this place, it never occurred to me that it would be either good or inexpensive. After years of walking past it, I decide to pop in... and it turns out that it's both good and inexpensive.

Also, there are some fine looking Vietnamese men who frequent this place. If that matters. And yes, I'm afraid it does. For me. #thisismyconfession.
author: Sean B.

description:
A major fan since it first opened at this location and happy to hear that they expanded to two other locations to spread its banh mi greatness!

Growing up, I definitely had my share of banh mi. Whether it be from commercial chains like Lee's Sandwiches, mom and pop shops in San Jose or Little Saigon-Santa Ana, or actually experiencing it as street food in Vietnam, I've had the opportunity to try some good (and bad!) banh mi.

Dinosaurs does a good job of staying true to the essence of the banh mi and integrating a modern take, San Francisco style. It's like you're eating Vietnam and SF, together! Let me break it down. The bread...is so good! It's not the traditional baguette, so it's different in that sense. The ingredients taste fresh, the daikon/carrots (do chua) are well pickled and meats well seasoned. 

My recommendation is the "Birds Nest" (The Meatball + The Crispy Tofu). Secret menu item? Maybe? I was exposed to this from my old roommate and ever since then, always get it. I enjoy it because of the flavor textures between the two. They work alone, but together, and add a bit of sriracha for kick...flavor explosion! 

Some may say it's a bit pricey for banh mi, but hey, it's San Francisco, what do you expect? Compared to surrounding restaurants in the area, it's a steal! 

Lastly, kudos for good and personable service (Shout out to Jon!).

Dinosaurs is Dino-Licious.
author: Vincent L.

description: We visited the Castro location.  Beautiful banh mi sandwiches and perfectly spiced.  The four of us ordered 2 specials, a chicken and a pork, along with an order of taro/tofu fresh rolls w/ peanut sauce.  Everything was wonderful and this was one of the best banh mi I have had....ever.  Son and daughter in law agree, and having vacationed in Vietnam recently they are saavy on the banh mi. The place was bustling but fairly fast to order at the counter.  About 15 seats inside and several outside.  Very friendly folks inside to help you with your order.
author: Michael B.

description: Love their spring rolls and their Vietnamese iced coffee! So delicious! I always bring a friend and get them hooked too.
author: Holly G.

description: Best Bahn Mi Sandwiches! I live in San Jose where there are many options for Bahn Mi (Vietnamese sandwiches) but if I could always drive to Castro for these I would. Clyde was super nice and helpful with exposing their menu as well suggesting new products! Its an inviting environment open natural lighting. On a nice day in the Castro outside seating is a great option. Food service is quick and friendly. The Food is excellent, will comeback often!
author: Sabrina V.

description:
Not my best banh mi. I like Duc Loi's a little better. But still a solid banh mi with good aioli. 
Definitely one of the better food choices for the Castro food scene.
author: Andy L.

description: Super creative and yummy restaurant! I love Tuna sandwich. Higher priced than other Vietnamese sandwich places, but the quality is so much better!!
author: Aliyah H.

description: Bread was good. Chicken was chewy. Way too many carrots. Price and atmosphere were ok. I'm a little spoiled on my Vietnamese food typically.
author: Khalid N.

description:
My friend and I had a lunch date and it was her very first time having banh mi. I knew this would be a good place to go. 

We both got crispy tofu but her sandwich had chicken added. 

Normally I'd get the special or shaking beef but a friend wanted to try pescatarianism for two weeks. Luckily, Dinosaur's crispy tofu is always ON POINT. Most places have tofu banh mi that are kinda soggy and too oily but their fried shredded tofu and taro is awesome. My friend agreed: she kept raving about it! 

I have yet to find a better tofu sandwich.
author: Sofia R.

description: I got their summer rolls. It was pretty mediocre. I would NOT recommend them. The other food may be good.
author: Lina H.

description: Delicious sandwiches, fast preparation and good service. Grilled pork sandwich is the best.
author: Frank S.

description:
Stopped by Dinosaurs for the first time 07/10/16, and I must say their bahn mi is fantastic! This place is a tiny little hole in the wall on 16th st. & Market. The entrance is small and difficult to see due to construction on the building it is in so it may take you a moment to find it, the entrance is on 16th st. 

On the inside the sandwich shop is tiny and probably can only seat a dozen or so customers at a time. Fortunately it was not very busy when I went so I was able to get a seat easily. The menu is basic they have bahn mi sandwiches, spring roll appetizers, and some drinks.

The bahn mi is very good and very inexpensive. For about $7.00 you can get a sandwich loaded with meat, picked carrot, pickled daikon, cucumber, and jalapeños. I had the special "kare kare bahn mi" which features Filipino style beef and a creamy peanut fish sauce and it was DELICIOUS! The bread was crunchy, the sauce was creamy, the jalapeños spicy, and the pickled carrots & daikon slightly acidic. This was one of the best bahn mi sandwiches I've had in the city and it only cost $7.49. I have paid more for worse bahn mi sandwiches at many places in SF! 

Cool place, definitely worth stopping by if you're in the area. If I lived in this neighborhood of SF I would for sure be at Dinosaurs all the time. Their awesome "kare kare" special bahn mi is limited to only 10 per day so if you have the opportunity to get it, go for it!
author: Tomas K.

description:
I've come here many times for lunch, it is a great asset to the Castro and their avocado shake is delicious. Dinosaurs is located on the side of one of the weird SF street corners that sort of juts out (resulting in amazing architecture sometimes), and you can also access it through the tiny shopping center off Market St (next to Books Inc) or Sanchez (their actual address). I only include this info cause I've found myself getting turned around in trying to find it, depending on what direction I was coming from! 8)

Usually I get the beef Bahn mi sandwich, it's very flavorful and a good portion. The avocado shake is awesome, I order it with non-dairy milk and agave nectar to sweeten (I don't usually like agave but a staff member at one point recommended it this way, and it is very good). Take your time with the avocado shake and don't drink it too fast or you will wind up with a stomachache! 

I was disappointed to learn last time I went in (and is perpetually happening with many of my favorite go-to spots in SF) that they raised their prices. What used to be a cheap, filling sandwich for about $6 now somewhere around $8 (after tax). While I get that it's SF, it's pricey, and many local businesses have to raise prices to keep up, it is somewhat disheartening to see your favorite places raise their prices.

But it's okay, Dinosaurs, I still love you and will eat your sandwiches.
author: Megan D.

description: This place is a MUST GO TO before heading out to Dolores park for the afternoon! Their sandwiches are flavorful and filling. Make sure to get the grilled pork sandwich. A bit pricey but worth it. Also bonus points because they were playing 90s R&B when I went in and their customer service was on point. Wish I had a Dinosaurs in San Jose!
author: M R.

description:
Pretty good Vietnamese sandwiches!! This place is pretty small with some outdoor seating. 

The sandwiches were around $7 each, which is pretty expensive in my opinion because I'm Asian and I usually go to the hole-in-the-wall places to get $3 sandwiches in Chinatown. Haha. Regardless, the food was good! 

I got THE SPECIAL, which had roasted pork, slices of an asian pork loaf and pate. All of the sandwiches come with the fermented dikon and carrots, cilantro and jalapeño. It was a really great sandwich! I was filled with the meat and vegetables. The flavor was great and it was a really good size! 

Overall, I would go back to this place if I was near by and was craving some Vietnamese sandwiches! It's just a little pricey for my wallet. Give it a try when you're in the Castro!
author: Samantha N.

description: Excellent, authentic banh mi. Great hole in the wall location near the Castro and Mission neighborhoods. I ran the errand to pick up sandwiches for a buddy for an early lunch. I got a special menu item, thai peanut beef banh mi and my friend had the grilled pork. Mine was terrific and rave reviews of the grilled pork. Definitely check this place out.
author: Kevin G.

description: Depending on where you enter, it can be hard to find the store. The banh mis are pretty good! But a little bit pricey in my opinion. $8 for a tofu banh mi
author: Samantha W.

description:
Banh mi: 3.5 stars
Cafe de sua: 1 star

I came to Dinosaurs to pick up lunch for driving to SoCal. I ordered the special which has roasted pork and pork pate and all the usual daikon, cucumber, cilantro, jalapenos, and mayo. The sandwich was decent and large for a banh mi. It had all the right ingredients but the 'wow, yum' factor was missing. Maybe it's the way other places butter their bread or the freshness of their bread or something about the veggie:meat:bread ratio.... I can't say for sure, but whatever it is I was left underwhelmed.

The iced coffee was horrible. Normally Vietnamese coffee is sweet, strong, and rich. Theirs was so watered down and just plain bitter. Usually I let my cafe de sua sit for awhile because the coffee is too potent so I need the melted ice to dilute it. But as the ice melted in the cup, this drink only got worse. I threw it out and it was probably more than half full. 

I still hold the belief you can find a cheaper and better tasting banh mi elsewhere and I'll pass on the coffee.
author: Danielle G.

description: Tried the chicken & shrimp roll and it was great! 3 large rolls and you get to choose the sauce. The peanut sauce was way too thick, it tasted more like peanut butter; it depends on your preference. Kare kare beef special had great seasonings and a delight to eat. I will try the grilled chicken bahn mi next time. I also heard the mango & mint and lychee smoothies are top sellers. Def rec!
author: Noor S.

description: I'm a big fan of Vietnamese sandwiches, and this joint hits the mark I even enjoyed one for later, the meatballs aren't my favorite. I was drawn in by the name and artwork associated with the establishment because to frank the location is rather polluted with street folk. sandwiches overall  But great sandwiches with simple sides and the fresh rolls with that peanut sauce. yes I'm living for it!
author: Thurston T.

description:
I'm not sure what the name means, and it's probably as much a non sequitur as finding a Vietnamese sandwich shop in the Castro. But I would expect the place to be more playful than it is - maybe a life-size Godzilla action figure that waves hello or at least a poster for "Land of the Lost", not the Will Ferrell version of course. No, it's just a nondescript space on the back-end of that mini-mall complex no one really knows is there except when I stop by Books Inc, or when maybe you go to that tiny sushi place I also forget is there inside. Dinosaurs is not really on Market either.

It flanks the 16th Street entrance to the mall, which I'm sure is the reason I never noticed it before. Six banh mi sandwiches are offered, as well as a few pre-packaged things like salad and spring rolls. Since this was my maiden voyage into prehistoric times, I thought I should give the sandwiches a try first. Like probably everyone else, I ordered the $5 Special, which has slices of roasted pork and "fancy pork loaf" and a smear of pate in between a crispy-crusted French roll with plenty of cilantro, shreds of pickled carrots and daikon, slices of chili peppers, and spears of cucumber (see photo).

In other words, it was prepared with nice authenticity and tasted quite delicious. I spared myself half the roll simply to avoid the carbs, but I couldn't help but also order the $4.75 Crispy Tofu as a chaser. In between the same type of French roll with the same toppings were fried tofu shards that reminded me of the French-fried onions you used to get in the cardboard cans, as well as rice noodles and a tofu-based mayo that was vegan-friendly (they call it "vegenaise") (see photo). This turned out to be quite good, too, though I have to say the oil content on the tofu was a bit overwhelming.

Good thing I followed the tip of a fellow Yelper and ordered extra cucumbers to moisten the sandwich with a bit more fresh crunch. So here's the deal - they're about twice the price of the sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich on Larkin in Little Saigon where everyone is willing to wait in line and ignore the aggressive vagrants on the sidewalk. And honestly, those gems are the best deal in town because they are done right. On the other end of the spectrum are the more designer banh mi creations at Bun Mee (sic) on Fillmore where you end up paying $6.50 for their special combo. Dinosaurs falls right in the middle which is fine by me.

FOOD - 4 stars...authentic banh mis well turned and pretty satisfying
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...generic space in a mall with a few tables
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...very quiet and preparation is hidden from view
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice ingredients and a fair price point make this outlier a worthwhile place to grab and go
author: Ed U.

description: Was near Market in the Castro today when I walked by this place that sells Vietnamese sandwiches. It has an artfully created menu and offers a slightly more interesting experience for Vietnamese sandwiches. I had the Shaken Beef sandwich and it was good. Not the cheapest place to get Vietnamese sandwiches, but not expensive either.
author: Denise C.

description: I got the chicken & shrimp spring roll and it was good at a reasonable price! I give this place only a 3 star because it's standard and you can get same thing anywhere else.
author: David T.

description:
This place has a run down feel and hipster vibe at the same time. Their menus are creative, portions are big, and they all seem to be pretty tasty! A sandwich was enough to make a guy full and even attempt to save the half for tomorrow's lunch (until everyone else shared a small bite each from the leftover).

It's a very reliable place to have a quick casual bite! 

(One less star because of lack of seating available. Recommend to-go's)
author: Becky M.

description:
Hole in the wall, very small, can be difficult to find.
Pork bahn mi was great!
Great bread.
author: H O.

description:
While their Banh Mi's are not the most authentic, they certainly are delicious and VERY filling. Often times, I am content after just eating half but a part of me who doesn't like to waste ends up eating the other..go figure!

It's probably one of the most annoying locations as far as congestion and parking but if ever I'm in the area I will drop by and get the grilled pork or combination pork, specifically, with NO cilantro and extra pickled veggies! I have yet to try the crispy tofu, so perhaps I'll add that to the list next time around.
author: Petra S.

description:
"I once was blind, but now, I see."

Was skeptical when I saw youngings with tattoos and beanies tryna make bahn mi. I was like aw hell naw. It's a simple sandwich, but far from simple to perfect. However their staff is watched over by a Vietnamese (I assume) papa and I'm sure everything goes by him. 

The sandwich: the special: BOMB. Freaking explosive hellapeno, dat creamy irony pate, then the chewy tender BBQ pork and finally the refreshing  crunch of the pickled daikon and cucumber and carrot - that sandwich was a bonafide motherf***er. Seriously. 

GOODJOB !
author: Luther C.

description:
Fantastic inexpensive sandwiches right in the heart of the Castro.

The crispy beef sandwich I ordered was well-seasoned, loaded with fresh vegetables, and on the perfect bread--crunchy crust with a soft interior. I added some Sriracha for extra heat but the flavors stood on their own. My partner had a pork sandwich which was equally tasty,

The papaya salad, however, was disappointing. The dressing was good enough but generic. The shrimp had obviously been cooked a while ago and were becoming a tad mealy. At least the papaya was crisp and fresh. Stick with the sandwiches.

The best part of the visit is that there was no line and only a short wait in the middle of a weekend day. this is a time when most shops in the Castro are packed. We were able to get a seat outdoors on a sunny San Francisco day.
author: Christopher W.

description: Very nice people, good fillings but the bread is just all wrong for a bahn mi. The crunchy exterior with soft interior isn't there. If you're OK with a denser bun then definitely check it out but I'm a traditionalist when it comes to bahn mi.
author: Kai T.

description:
The traveling cat finds himself in the Castro/mission area once again with his fellow spotty cat, and he finds himself wandering the streets looking for a quick lunch stop. Completely overwhelmed by expensive nearby options, you can imagine my delight when coming across this little sandwich shop down a random street! Time to give it a try! 

Both me and my cat decided to go for the grilled chicken sandwich. This place is very tiny, with a bit of seating inside, and a few tables outside in front. Pretty simple options here, nothing too fancy. I noticed some people seemed to be regulars and we're making large orders, seems to be a good sign! 

The sandwiches arrived quickly and I was pleasantly surprised to take my first bite! A lot of Vietnamese sandwiches have really tough bread I notice, but the bread here was nice and soft much to my relief. Nice and warm, and perfectly cooked and tender chicken, this was exactly what I was looking for today! ^ ^ 

Price wise, it's definitely slightly on the higher side of the standard pricing for Vietnamese sandwiches, but I would say that it was well worth it. 

Definitely stop by if you are in the area! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
One of the better banh mi places in SF, although not "authentic" I would say this is cali-mi, kinda like how Chevy's is TexMex? Yea well Dinosaurs is CaliMi. 

First off, their sandwiches are huge. I am usually content with just eating half but a whole will get you stuffed. Spring rolls and the papaya salad are below mehhh here. Stick with sandwiches. They're flavorful, give you a good amount of meat and a decent amount of the pickled carrots (love that ish!)

P.S. I DO prefer the Ocean Ave location though. Crispy tofu is actually crispy there (sorry yours wasn't AMP!)
author: Susy C.

description:
RAWR RRR RAA RRWR
STOMP STOMP STOMP
GROOOOA RWARRWR

translation:

Liked it. Will be back.
(moves around a bit)
Indeed open past 7.
author: Dan B.

description:
Came here with my cousin because it was close to where we were staying. We bought 2 specials, a shrimp spring roll, and the mint mango drink. The special was very good, not the best I have had but I enjoyed it. The shrimp spring roll was delicious as well. I liked the mint mango drink, the mango flavor was pretty strong and had a minty aftertaste at the end. 

We went during lunch hour and the place is very small so it was packed. Since we were living very close by we brought the food home, but if you are hoping to eat there it might be a bit difficult. My cousin really liked the look of their menu and they also have a small arcade game inside.
author: Pamela T.

description:
This is the best Bánh Mi I've had in this city. It's the perfect combination that cheap Bánh Mi style slightly infused with San Francisco quality.

Fresh baguettes, great tasting meats, and that delicate blend of cilantro, daikon, jalapeños, pate and mayo into Bánh Mi perfection! 

Get the Special for $5.25!
author: Phil G.

description:
I don't know why I tried a vietnamese place in noe valley and had expectations of a good vietnamese sandwich. 
Unfortunately I've grown up on eating vietnamese sandwiches in San Jose so my expectations for Viet sandwiches are pretty high. 
All sandwiches include pickled carrots and daicon, cucumber, cilantro, jalepenos, and mayo. I got the special ($7.39) which had roasted pork, special loaf pork, and pork pâté. The roasted pork was dry and had no flavor except salty, the special loaf pork (cha in Vietnamese) was average but was sliced very thinly, and the pork pâté (spreadable ground meat) was good. I like my vietnamese sandwiches flavorful which usually means well cooked juicy meat with pickled daicons. Unfortunately the meat was just there and dry and I could barely tell the veggies were pickled. 

The only reason I'm not giving this place 1 star is because I think my expectations are too high. If you've never had a real Vietnamese sandwich, this place might be fine for you. But if you have, then this place is way overpriced for just a sandwich since Viet sandwiches are usually $4-5 for a good one.
author: Tiffany G.

description:
This place is solid. Sandwiches are about $7 and delicious. Vegan friendly

The Special is my favorite, but I'd eat there even if I had to pick randomly from the menu.

If you're in the neighborhood and need a fast & tasty meal, you cannot go wrong with Dinosaurs.
author: Tim R.

description:
Dinosaurs is the T. Rex of Vietnamese sandwiches: large, mighty, and always ready to take another bite. Without being hyperbolic, this place is home to the best sandwiches, Vietnamese or not, I have ever had in my life. The baguettes strike the perfect balance between a certain exuding soft freshness and crackling crispness along the outside layer, holding together the deliciousness of the ingredients within. 

These are people who understand how each component of a sandwich complements the other, from the way the picked carrots balance out the light flavor of cucumbers, to the seasoned mayonnaise soaking into all the in-betweens, everything comes together with a delightfully fresh and tangy elegance.  

The sandwiches are consistently great, too. I've been coming here for awhile now and have yet to be disappointed. Their menu serves up traditional affair for what can go into a Vietnamese sandwich, along with some non-traditional stuff. I'm particularly partial to the mushroom sandwich, but you really can't go wrong here. Everything asides the sandwiches themselves (i.e., fresh spring rolls) are admittedly not as good, but I'll forgive them for it since that's not the focus here.

Overall, a great sandwich shop that provides a delicious, innovative spin on an ethnic classic. Trust me, you want to eat here.
author: Anthony W.

description: Finally got to try their " Special Sandwich" Vietnamese sandwich! It was tasty!!! I was worried that the amount of sandwiches they have to create to fill the endless lines of hungry people who bring the quality down, but I was happily proven wrong! Even the time to wait for your sandwich wasn't that long which is important when you come by for lunch! Will definitely come back to try the other sandwiches!
author: Geraldine R.

description:
Banh mi here is delicious and very filling for a cheap price and reasonable wait time. They are clean and simple, not a messy sandwich like Ike's.

Remember to checkin to Yelp to get 10% off your order - which can be used each time you go. The Special and the Grilled Chicken are my typical choices.

It gets busy during peak hours on the weekend, but overall haven't had to wait too long. Sometimes it can be difficult to get seats but luckily sandwiches are pretty portable.

The only thing that bothers me is that the bread is very hard and thick, so if you just had a dentist appointment, you might want to avoid this place. 

Overall a cheap, healthy sandwich option that satisfies the banh mi craving if you can't make it out to the Tenderloin.
author: Elisa L.

description:
I was actually looking for a deli-type place in the Castro to get a quick sandwich made for take away when I came across Dinosaurs! What a great find! I love Vietnamese sammies! And when I perused through the yelp photos, I found one of a toy from that old show Dinosaurs from the '90s! That was from my childhood, the one that was live action and it was about a family of dinosaurs. Nostalgic. Then I found another photo and it was of a little Domo wearing a dinosaur/godzilla costume and that sealed it. I was going to come to Dinosaurs for a banh mi sandwich. 

It was actually a little hard for me to find - once you find the address, you'll have to go down the stairs and keep walking towards the back to find it. It's a small place with just a few tables on the inside, and some seating outside. There are a couple of sandwiches on the menu, including vegan options. They also have salads and spring rolls. 

I ordered The Special sandwich: roasted pork + pork loaf + pork pate. You can also add on extras to your sandwich. I was curious about the crispy tofu, so I added that on to my banh mi. I also ordered a Thai iced tea. The sammie was delicious. The bread was fresh and lightly toasted and the pickled veggies were so yummy. They packed in a good amount of meat and veggies and of course the jalapenos added that extra kick that I love. The fillings were spilling out as I was munching on my sammie. The crispy tofu was like fried pieces of shredded tofu - not sure if that's exactly what they were, but they weren't like slice of patties of tofu that were fried like I originally imagined. They were good and added a nice texture to the sandwich. Oooh, and the Thai iced tea was good too - went well with my sammie.  And I liked that they offered vegan options - my friends really liked the portobello banh mi and the crispy tofu banh mi. Will definitely come back the next time I'm in the Castro to try the grilled pork banh mi!
author: Sylvia K.

description: Pretty good vietnamese sandwiches! I probably like this place's sandwich more than DragonEats. Really though, any places where a banh mi is this expensive is not worth it if you can make your way to an authentic viet place. The best banh mis I get are all from hole in the wall places. I guess now that hipsters have caught on to banh mi, expect this upcharging to continue.
author: Kelly D.

description:
Dinosaurs, I really wanted to you love you.  Because you see, I love Banh Mi.  Ever since I moved from NY (and away from Banh Mi Saigon in Chinatown) I have been on the search for a delicious substitute.  This quest has led me to Out the Door, Bun Mee, and now to Dinosaurs.  Here's the overview:

Restaurant:  Small, divey, holl-in-the-wall.  I dig it.  4/5.  Nothing special, but I don't want anything special.  (Banh Mi Saigon is in the back of jewelry store).  Clean enough.  

Service:  Friendly, fast, offered suggestions.  Above average.  4/5.

Food:  
Spicy Tuna:  I guess I should have read the menu more closely.  In my mind I was thinking sushi style spicy tuna.  Not Tuna Salad Sandwich style.  I haven't eaten tuna like this since I was in college.  2/5
The Special:  The positives:  Bread is perfect for a Banh Mi.  Crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside.  The pickled vegi's and cilantro was good.  The pork pate was okay.  Overall this was an average tasting sandwich.  3/5.  
Pork and Shrimp Spring Rolls:  4/5.  The best part of this was the peanut sauce.  

Overall this place is a 3.5/5 for me.  I will go back and give this place another chance because I feel it is a good value, the staff is friendly (and they have cherry coke in the fountain :-)).
author: Paul W.

description: A friend recommended this place for us to grab a quick bite. The sandwiches were pretty delish but for ~$8 a bahn mi sandwich I felt there should have been a drink thrown in for a complete meal. I think I could get about 2 bahn mi sandwiches or maybe 3 if I visited Lee's sandwiches or the like. Hence the 3 stars. Don't get me wrong the sandwiches were perfectly good but the price point was a bit high.
author: W A.

description:
The name alone makes you want to like it. This is a really uncomplicated place that was once five stars awesome. Unfortunately they went and jacked their prices crazy high. Not one of these sandwiches deserve to be more than $6. 

It's a quality sandwich and their shakes are always awesome- their avocado shake inspired me to get a blender! I just can't get over spending $8 for a Vietnamese sandwich. Get your price point in a better range and this would be a 4 star review.
author: Andrew S.

description: Overall, that establishment was a four star rating. It was a little small which was probably one of my leading factors of not fully given it a five star, but overall the business was great the service was awesome, and the food was delicious I highly recommend this place and I will be back.
author: Zack T.

description:
BEST Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. I go to the Castro and Pacifica shops all the time. Food is always delicious, always fast and the workers are very nice.

I only tried the crispy tofu sandwich, but my friend really likes the supreme and mushroom sandwiches.
The vegetarian spring rolls were really good too, but didn't fill me up like the sandwiches.
author: Regina M.

description:
I'm used to the skinnier banh mi, but these may be even better. I love the crunchy bread mmmm.. I'm a big fan of the classic special pork sandwich (no mayo, extra jalapeno), but the shaking beef or grilled pork or chicken are excellent alternatives when I wanna switch it up too. I was doing the vegetarian thing for a hot minute and had to resort to the tofu and that was a sad day because it was really dry... and I had to look around at everyone else enjoying their juicy meaty sandwiches.

ANYWAY I like grabbing sandwiches and hiking up to Corona Heights for a lil picnic with a view!
author: Vivian H.

description:
The food quality is great and my favorite sandwiches are the special and shaking beef. The Thai ice tea is also really solid. There are some comments on the inflated price but I would comment back that it's difficult, if not impossible,  to find food that cheap in the surrounding area. It's most likely a matter of competing prices. 

Make sure to mention jalapeños if you don't want that spicy (is assumed into the order if you don't make any adjustments).
author: Nick W.

description: Been here a bunch of times. I'd still prefer going to a banh mi place in the tendenob/tenderloin, but for this area, it's solid banh mi joint. They've raised their prices by 50c it seems some time in the past year, but even at $5.93 for a grilled pork sandwich, it's still cheaper than most things around (looking fwd to M&L reopening!). The pork is my favorite; I wouldn't bother with the portobello again.
author: Linus W.

description: Banh mi and spring rolls are atop my favorite foods list and Dinosaur is one of my go to spots in SF.  They do both well and are reasonably priced for SF.  They have multiple locations around the city and are consistent across (although Ocean Beach is my favorite!).
author: Kevin N.

description: went there wednesday night before thanksgiving and had the worst bahnmi in the history of bahnmi.  my friend ordered the special and i ordered the roast pork.  the meat was a single layer and the vegetables were spaced out thin.  my sandwich was really dry.  for the record - i have been going to dinosaurs for a couple years now and this is the first time i have ever had a problem.  sad thing is, i broke my diet to eat their sandwich.  what a waste of time and money.
author: Cin D.

description:
Dinosaurs, the name says it all. This sandwich place is tops for one of the best sandwich shops in the city. Dinosaurs is retreat from the typical sandwich shops in the city. They offer the classic Banh mi but they make it simple and delicious. The classic Banh Mi never fails here. 3/3 times, I have had nothing but the special. Consisting of pate, pickled veggies, it is packed with pork pork and more PORK. Half of the sandwich you are satisfied, but its hard to say no to the other half of the sandwich, when each bite is flakey, crisp, flavorful and juicy. For the vegetarians and vegans, there is crispy tofu, and for lighter protein waters, BBQ chicken is also an option.  

Sandwiches range from 5.00-5.25, and they also offer delicious and fresh spring rolls for those who want something on the lighter side.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
I believe they raised their prices. Not sure about the value anymore since it was already the most expensive bahn mi in the city I've tried. Still same quality. Very nice
staff.
author: Katie A.

description:
Their sandwiches are always great, I love the chicken and the grilled pork options. Throw on some sriracha and you'll be in heaven!

The watermelon litchi smoothie is also great. A refreshing, simple treat.
author: Chris C.

description:
After a morning of urban hiking, it was time for lunch. Protip: if you're coming from Market Street, it's a little bit hard to find. You will not see it on the street, but you have to go into a building and down a hallway to find it. When you do get there, it's really small - a few seats on the inside and a few tables on the street. Luckily, we were able to snag a table on the street since it was a nice day. I got The Special  which is 2 kinds of pork, pate, daikon, cucumbers, jalapenos, and mayo on a baguette roll. Considering how big and full it looked, I was really excited, but when I took a bite, I thought it was just ok. Since there wasn't much sauce (except for the mayo), it didn't have much flavor. The pork didn't have much flavor, but the veggies on top were pretty good. The bread was ok. I would have loved it if it was crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, but it was just a normal roll. 

Overall, it's smaller than it looks. You can eat it all! I did it! The sandwich is just okay. At $7-$8 a sandwich, I rather take my money elsewhere.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Decently priced banh mis that were delicious! I got the Special, and it was really filling with the perfect amount of meat, pate, and pickled veggies. My friend and I also split the vegetarian spring rolls with tofu and jicama, and got it with the peanut sauce. It tasted really fresh with the perfect amount of crunch! Finally, the watermelon lychee smoothie was freshly made with watermelon and lychee, and came with jellies in the cup. The cashier was also super nice and brought out my smoothie to me. Overall, so good and I would definitely go back again!
author: Grace C.

description:
After coming here more recently I feel like I need to update my review. The sandwiches are now both more expensive and significantly smaller. The flavors are still great, but the quality of ingredients seems to have weakened a bit. They changed their bread so it's more crusty than fluffy (I'm sure some people like this) and the jalapeños on all of our sandwiches were quite dry and not fresh. 
I'm sure I'll still visit...but it just isn't the same deal as it used to be.
author: Cara K.

description:
Damn you, Saigon Sandwich for changing your closing time!

I have a soft spot for Saigon Sandwich because I grew up eating their Combo (Dac Biet) Banh Mi but since they now close at 5 pm instead of 6 pm, it's possible for me to go there unless I get off work early. This led me on a mad search on Yelp for a banh mi place (other than Lee's) that doesn't close at 4 or 5 pm. Then comes Dinosaurs, 4 Stars on Yelp and closes at 10 PM! SCORE?

MENU
*BANH MI ($4.75): The Special (like a Combo), The Pork, The Chicken, The Meatball, The Spicy Tuna and The Crispy Tofu
*STEAMED BUNS ($3): Pork and Chicken
*SPRING ROLLS ($4.50): Pork w/ Shrimp, Chicken w/ Shrimp and Tofu

They also have a variety of snacks (chips and hi-chews) and drinks. CC's accepted. 

I couldn't decide between two sandwiches so I decided to get both, eat half from each and save the rest for later. At $4.75 each, there are about $1-$1.75 more than your banh mi in TL, but you have to remind yourself they have no competition in the Castro and rent is much higher.

Given the good reviews and the super friendly young man that works there, I really wanted to like Dinosaurs and was hoping to give nothing less than 4 stars; that's until I tasted the sandwiches...

MY ORDER
The key to a solid banh mi is the bread. Dinosaurs uses a hearty French baguette that was perfectly crunchy with a chewy bite. However, the fillings and lack of authentic flavors (i.e. savory, salty, tangy and spicy) are where they lost major points with me.

*CRISPY TOFU - Fried Tofu, Rice Noodles, Taro & Veganaise - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yC5ATYRQah7MjeTiRsGcvA?select=QGLzxXzvamQ9Smcl15thMA
As recommended by Yelpers, this was rather a disappointing banh mi. The combination of fried tofu and taro strips and fried noodles made for an extremely dry, yet oily sandwich. The pickled carrots and daikon were sliced too thinly causing it to dry out. It also lacked acidity which didn't help cut through the richness. In short, the banh mi tasted like fried onion strings between two slabs of bread.

*THE SPECIAL - Roasted Pork, Fancy Pork Loaf & Pate - 3 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yC5ATYRQah7MjeTiRsGcvA?select=yKHsH3VjPl2L7sh7DtffIA
Inside The Special were roast pork and cha la (steamed pork) and a gentle smearing of pate; sans the headcheese which is normally in an authentic banh mi. The meat was sliced unusually thin as opposed to thicker slices. Again, I found this banh mi to be dry although not as dry as the crisp tofu one because of the pate. It was missing most of the essential flavor profiles I'm use to: tender, savory porkyness (roast pork was dry and bland), creaminess from the mayo (was used very sparingly), saltiness from the soy sauce (didn't detect any) and tanginess from the pickled carrots and daikon (was dried out).

It's a shame I can't RAWR over Dinosaurs. I guess it's back to the land of crackheads and pee infested sidewalks to get my Banh Mi "Fix".
author: Cherylynn N.

description: twice the price of Saigon on Larkin, and almost as good.  So, if in the area and in a hurry, it's definitely worth a stop.  The sandwich would be greatly improved if they got a harder, less doughy roll and/or remove a bit of the core before building it.
author: Josh K.

description:
This place is no-nonsense and offers pretty cheap, super delicious foods. 

The spring rolls are great (I've only had the shrimp, but I've heard chicken is good as well) - super fresh and refreshing.

My personal favorite is the grilled pork bahn mi - that shit is GOOOD. You can get double the meat for $2 and walk away with a super tasty sandwich for $9. I get it sans jalepenos (way too spicy for me).

If you're looking for a place to pick up lunch or a quick bite to grab and bring to Dolo (but not so much food as Ike's) then this is your place.

Flavorful. Fun. Cheap. Delicious.

A+
author: Andrea D.

description:
The Special was very good sandwich, with a lot of meat!
Little meat but still very good sandwich, the Grilled Pork was delicious!

The rolls (shrimp, apple, cucumber and grilled pork) with peanut sauce are ok.
author: Arnaud H.

description: Tasty food but some serious health code violations while we ate there. Construction was happening on the store front and workers were sanding painted walls with dust flying all over our food and into the kitchen.  The restaurant didn't seem to mind or say anything.
author: Philip L.

description:
What I ordered:
+ Shaking beef sandwich (A)

I'm not a stickler about my banh mi, I am pretty satisfied with almost anything wrapped in french bread so there was no way Dinosaurs could mess that up. 

Not only did they not mess up, they hit it out of the park! Not just out of the park, that ball went all the way back in time to the Mesozoic era (is that why it's called Dinosaurs?).

Every bite seemed like I was being born again. The vinegar and cilantro flirted with my tongue and the beef went in the for the kill. The bread is the wingman but oh man what wingman, soaked in delicious sauce, it's a prime example of how to compliment the fillings, not overwhelm them. They certainly don't kid around with the filling, it was easily a meal fit for a human size T-Rex (is that why it's called Dinosaurs?). 

I bit my finger, I didn't realize I had finished the second half. Not even a little stray meat to be found. My mouth was still salivating, my brain told my stomach there was still more. It's like walking down the stairs thinking there's one more step when there's not - but worse. I let out a chewbacca-pterodactyl cross screech in agony. That's why it's called Dinosaurs, right?
author: Jason O.

description:
The last 3 times I've been there, the head cashier / (kitchen manager?) was visibly angry, agitated, or annoyed. Normally I'd understand but on 3 separate visits over a few months' span, it's starting to bother me now. Slamming chairs around, being short and impolite with customers, I have to dial back my review a star.

In addition, their OrderAhead system still requires the patron to wait in the regular ordering line to pick up the sandwich, which makes it impossible to run in and grab your sandwich if in a hurry or when trying to drive past and get it.
author: Ryan D.

description:
This place is great, small little shop with a great atmosphere.

I would come here from work and grab a Banh Mi and a Thai Iced tea. Great prices and great sandwhich's.
author: Mark B.

description: The banh mi's here are good but if you're looking for delicious and cheap banh mis, go to saigon sandwich or any other banh mi store in that area. The sandwiches here are decent but not worth the price, in my opinion.
author: Derrick W.

description: Love all the Dinosaurs locations! Their sandwiches are amazing! Their spring rolls are the best!!!! And they have pretty good drinks! Lastly - the guy who served us was very very nice.
author: Nina M.

description:
The sandwiches are really good and the spring rolls are on-point too!

I've been the Dinosaurs a few times now and the sandwiches are great! I always order "the special" and love how the sandwich is pretty balanced and loaded with food. I would also recommend ordering the pork and shrimp spring rolls as well! The rolls are solid and won't fall apart upon your first bite and are well seasoned.

The shop itself is tucked away in the side of a building and is relatively quiet to sit outside and eat. If you're in the area and looking to grab a Vietnamese sandwich, try this place!
author: Nick C.

description:
The sandwiches, the shakes, the papaya salad, the spring rolls, EVERYTHING here is amazing. SO delicious and fresh. I could eat here everyday. Avocado shake sounds weird, but you have it with a sandwich and add some sriracha it's perfection! The watermelon litchi is pretty good too. 

They have a few locations in the bay and always offer discounts on yelp and PayPal. You can order ahead and pay thru paypal as well. They also offer rewards program. The staff is super friendly and I've never had any issues at any of the locations. 

Just thinking about it is making me hungry. It's definitely gonna be lunch today!
author: Jay N.

description:
Tried this place for the first time and loved it! It definitely seems like a luck of the draw thing for crowds - empty when I walked in, suddenly packed 5 minutes later. 

It's small and unassuming but the food is great. I'm glad I come to the area once in a while because I'll definitely be checking this place out again!
author: M. R.

description: The sandwiches are goooood. I tried the shaking beef with no mayo. The staff are very friendly and accommodating with smiles on their faces. Large selection of drinks and chips available too. I'm considering to go back for more within the hour.
author: Christian T.

description:
The only reason I found this place was because I saw people sitting outside! Without them, you would've totally missed this place, even if you looked for it hahaha

Anyways, I order the Special because they wouldn't name it Special if it wasn't. But to be honest, there wasn't too much that resonated with me. It was like an almost above average viet sandwich. The roasted pork was dry, but the pork loaf and pate were good. The sauce tasted just mostly like mayo, which I enjoy so I guess it wasn't that bad for me? But I wouldn't think that's how you generally want your spread to taste like.. The baguette was good; soft on the inside, super crunchy on the outside. I also had a watermelon smoothie/slushy. I didn't want lychee jelly in it so I asked to exclude it and it turned out to just be a watermelon slush. Not too special. 

Dinosaur didn't necessarily wow me, but it was a solid sandwich/meal. I'll come back to try their other options. The wait was also maybe longer than I wanted, but oh well. Not bad, but not incredible. I like Bun Mee on Fillmore better, but I'll probably still come back!
author: Holly P.

description:
This place is one of my favorite Vietnamese sandwich places. I'm addicted to the watermelon lychee smoothie. It's very refreshing on a hot day. 
I have had the spring rolls and the shaking beef many times. They are awesome.
author: Tanner B.

description: I always come here or go to the Pacifica location. Great service and the presentation and product never fails.
author: Jonathan R.

description: One of the best bahn mi's I've ever had. I recommend you get the sliced beef one, along with a Thai iced tea. Usually the bread of bahn mi's are hard and chewy, but this place seems to get their bread delivered fresh on the daily. You definitely will not be disappointed
author: Ajay S.

description: Delicious Banh mi and spring rolls! We ordered pork and shrimp spring rolls and a grilled pork sandwich. The portions were HUGE. The bread was soft and the pork crispy, just the way we liked it. Unfortunately, they raised their prices a bit and each banh mi is now around $7. But, still a great place to pick up food to-go. Also, don't forget to check-in on yelp -- sometimes they have a 10% discount.
author: Connie L.

description:
Round 2.  This time as a vegetarian!  There is a groupon good for $20 at this place. The tofu banh mi and the portobello banh mi was good. The coffee is pretty strong so look out, prepare to be wide awake. The Thai iced tea was too sweet for me but the bf loved it. Lastly we got the vegetarian spring rolls and they were pretty good. Thumbs up.  I like how it's family owned. Reminds me of home. 

Check out the artwork on the walls while you are there. Neat stuff.
author: J. T.

description:
I had forgotten to write my review about this small banh mi sandwich shop, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8F4OYsC1qb76BMdIeWblYg/l that only has 4 tables. The temporary "3 for 2" offer (normally priced $4.50-$4.75 each, w/offer it's about $3 each) on Mon-Thu 4-7pm, is worthwhile. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Eaz95-XvgFHONk5GVvleyQ/l

Update: ALL sandwiches are now $4.75 each.
 
I still think that Saigon sandos and Y&Y Deli are the best in the city. But this is a good runner up, and the only banh mi shop in this area. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QhisfjBwBKxdSycfXyLtBQ/l The filling has the right balance between meat amount and pickled veggies. And sometimes they use long baguettes, instead of rolls. 

The short menu includes 6 sandwiches: The pork, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Go8pDygJ10R_Qhl5yynQHw/l meatball, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FpEXMMuBbskFDqaTcjh4Ug/l and chicken sandwiches http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/g_xNv09HQib1rzZhs6YTpw/l are typical good banh mi. But don't overlook the tuna, it's delicious. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9CbEIeSQh-lizXFHnWOsFA/l The special (aka. dac biet) has a generous amount of ham and cha lua, better than other shops. http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vmHF6GQCPD4xX-KumGiQzg/l And the crispy tofu is very unique, thin strands of taro, noodles and tofu are fried to resemble overcooked shredded meat (the first vegan SF banh mi I've ever seen). http://media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RP2nzIkCJh265gIpZ8aE9Q/l

The shop is somewhat hidden, so the 16th street entrance http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/jpqWpOQs6cVnGskbUC1iGA/l doesn't have much foot traffic. And the entrance on Market street is easy to miss. Only marked by a small street sign. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pr5UyvAVOEh7roZdtjhNMw/l Walk down this corridor http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/V_g0Tzd5xVWW4AJUmOn8Wg/l and down the stairs http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/J0hrGXIbEtezVwgt1jcAZQ/l until u see the red walls of the sandwich shop.

Good news! starting November 1st 2010, the shop will stay open until 10pm. Don't forget to pick a frequent buyer card (buy 9 sandos, get one free).
author: Luis C.

description: Dinosaurs is great & there's rarely a line. My favorite is the crunchy tofu. I'm not a vegetarian, but this sandwich is fantastic. Perfect soft-yet-crunchy bread, crisp fresh vegetables, perfect spicy sauce & the tofu is crunchy. We love this place. They have several tables, some outside. Friendly staff, nice place & great sandwiches.
author: Scott F.

description:
Really tasty sandwiches! Ordered "The Special" sandwich (i.e. pork with pork with pork) which was really savoury. The pork was actually a little tough at parts, but it tasted great! The pork paste was surprisingly delicious. All the meat went really well with the classic carrots/cucumbers in the sandwich.

The staff was also very friendly and helpful! The venue is pretty small, so you might have to go somewhere else to actually eat your sandwich, but if you can get a seat, the atmosphere is kind of quirky/playful (they even have an arcade machine!).
author: Drini C.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place but it has gotten a bit expensive. I usually don't pay more than $5 for a banh mi but they have killer vegan fish sauce.

I don't like the mushroom sandwich too much but enjoy the tofu one.

Also, the tofu used in the Spring rolls and sandwiches are the same so don't expect two different types of tofu.

It's hot so get a drink if you're a wimp when it comes to the peppers.
Tip: Check in on yelp so you get a discount!!
author: Julia Q.

description:
Living in SF is always great when out comes to theselection of food available from every corner of the planet.
Case in point - its absolutely unnecessary to go to Vietnam to get a bahn mi! 
I personally felt that the service we received here was a bit rough around the edges and the food was just alright, the bread was really dry and hard. So the search for a good Bahn Mi continues on from here.

I will say that the spring rolls were great.
author: Ben M.

description: Used to be one of my favorite spots. Sandwiches have consistently become smaller and less filled over the past two years, and they are almost always out of the Portobello bahn mi. I will not be coming back.
author: Alexander W.

description:
FOOD: This place has good banh mi sandwiches, but they're kind of pricey for the size and for what they are! I have found equal quality places for half the price. 

SERVICE: Service was a bit slow when I went, there was no line but the cashier didn't notice us standing there ready to order. 

VENUE: The place is really small with only a few tables. If it's a busy day you'll have to take your sandwiches to eat elsewhere.
author: Mary N.

description: Came here after my gym on the way home.  I tried the VN spring rolls - they were bland and  doesn't taste like VN rolls at all.  I know they are not catering to the VN people, so the flavors are not authentic.   Will come back and try their Banh Mi next time and see...
author: Tom V.

description: Dinosaurs has the largest and freshest spring rolls I've ever had! I got the combo of chicken and tofu, and even after working out, I could barely finish the rolls. They were delicious though, so I didn't let them go to waste. I love that you can choose a variety of sauces, and the apple inside the rolls is refreshing. This place is tiny, so if you have a group, it's best to order out.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I have nothing but good things to say about Dinosaur. But I want to quote my friend, "Dinosaur looks like a bunch of break dancers just decided to open up a Vietnamese sandwich shop." This is not a bad thing but it does look like it lol. Dinosaur is hard to find. I walked around Castro trying to find it around Halloween and was not even close to finding it. Finally, I found it weeks later after seeing a visible sign on Market street pointing to stairs leading down to a lower level where there were shops and businesses.

I found Dinosaurs and it is located right behind Bagdad Cafe, across from the library. The staff was very nice and greeted my friend and I. We ordered the grilled pork and that sandwich was above average and I want more! The pork was very flavorful and the sandwich itself had the perfect balance of pickled veggies and mayo. What I particularly loved was the bread! I won't reveal where they get their bread from, but that bread is MONEY! It is the perfectly toasted with the best crunch to it. I cannot wait to go back and a sandwich for under $5 that is filling enough? Why not right?
author: Danster L.

description:
That weekend lunch spot that always sounds like a good idea, it's a great go-to sandwich place if you want to nosh but not feel disgusted with yourself afterwards (I'm looking at you Ike's). 

THE FOOD:

Awesome, high quality Bahn Mi's, solid prices and a decent amount of choices. Kind of wish you could get a fried egg on the sandwiches though. 

THE SERVICE:

Always friendly, but a tad slow, especially when there is a line. They don't exactly crank these bad boys out. 

OTHER:

That good outdoor seating with solid people watching. Short walk to the park too.
author: Patrick T.

description:
So much better than castro tarts in regards to banh mi n Vietnamese coffee.  Had way more meat than the other place n the coffe did not taste weird. They did it right. But not your traditional type of banh mi. I usually order grilled pork, but they don't have that here. 
Got the special beef instead n it was just as tastey. 
Will definitely return!
author: Christi S.

description:
It took me forever to find this place.  It's in the Castro District-From Market look for Bagdad Cafe & walk down, it's on the Left, across from Eureka Valley/Harvey Milk Branch SF Public Library.

Tiny shop.  Order at the register.  There's only 5 tables inside, 9 chairs.  Most people take it to go.

I had a coupon from SF Weekly. Buy sandwich & drink, get 1 Sandwich FREE.  I got: The Special $4.75-roasted pork, fancy pork loaf & pate.  Nice crunchy toasted roll w/ typical Vietnamese sandwich stuff.  I liked it.

The Spicy Tuna $4.75 - chunk light tuna w/ spicy mayo.  Toasted roll & tuna w/ a mildly spicy mayo sauce.  I liked it.

Drink: They just have bottled drinks.  I got Yeo's soymilk.  Tasted fine.

My total was $6, credit cards taken. 

They have a Frequent Buyers card: Buy 9 sandwiches get 1 FREE!

Bathrooms: You need a key, they have separate men/women, but it's outside their shop - women's 2nd door to the right.  Had 2 stalls & 2 sinks.

Tip: They have some SF Weekly magazines in the shop.  Coupon in there.

Daily 10a-7p
Note: Starting 11/1 open until 10pm.
author: Ann L.

description:
I'm a hella picky about my Vietnamese sandwiches and I think these sandwiches are hella good! 

We got:
Roasted chicken $5
The shaking beef $6
Avocado shake $4.25
Mango mint $ 3.75
 
I would give this a 5 star, but the price it too high for Viet sandwiches. I guess ppl would find this cheap bc of the area it's located in. 

Would I come here again? If I am in the area, Hell yes. Would I come across the bridge for this? Nah... I'll get my yummy viet sandwiches for half the price in Oakland. 

You should definitely check out this Vietnamese-inspired sandwich spot!
author: Lien L.

description:
This place was bustling, which I love.  The prices were right and the food fresh.  Service was what it needed to be.

What I didn't love was the pretty limited menu.  I really enjoy non franchise places, but in this situation, I would choose Lee's sandwiches over Dinosaur.  I just like their sandwiches better.
author: R Clark G.

description:
Well, I know for damn sure; never go to Ike's on the weekends. I just noticed a fat-ass long line that reached well past and beyond the auto body and detailing shop. 

At the end of the long line and like five buildings away from Ike's is a brand new and little but cute Vietnamese deli.  Believe it or not, the line for tiny Ike's reached that far. This is the only Vietnamese Deli in the Castro and indeed a welcoming addition. For now, this little deli serves six kinds of Banh Mi sandwiches. 

I had one of the deli's six sandwiches; the Grilled Chicken Sandwich. For $4.50 (it appears to be the average price everywhere now), I get a slice of freshly cooked Grilled Chicken, julienned-slices carrots, daikon, cilantro and a couple slices of jalapeno in a warm crunchy roll. This tasty sandwich has all the fresh key-ingredients and a huge improvement from the last time I had a Banh Mi from Irving Street Deli. 

I also had a cool and refreshing Vita Chrysanthemum box drink for $1.00 with my sandwich. I like the fact that this is one of the very few places in the area that carries the Asian beverage. In my book, the Asian drink and Banh Mi is a great pair. This place also has Pepsi products as well.

I've also noticed many people were buying the Steamed Pork Bun. Another item I'll check out, which will be undoubtedly very soon. I hope the deli will have more items when I return. 

I used my Mastercard for my lunch. The young and energetic girl, made my sandwich, was very nice with a sunshine smile. 

If you have an empty stomach and have zero patient to wait in the long line for a sandwich from Ike's, this place makes a really good Banh Mi too. Consider this Vietnamese deli instead.
author: Matt G.

description: This place was a bit difficult to find since I had to navigate through the little indoor plaza, but it was well worth it. It was a surprisingly authentic vietnamese sandwich with a slight SF twist to it... if that makes sense. This sandwich doesn't skimp out on the meat and carrots, either- very filling and satisfying :)
author: Leesur S.

description:
Delicious, affordable fresh banh mi, spring rolls, and Vietnamese style salads. Not as cheap as in Little Saigon in Tenderloin, but I'm just grateful that good, fast Vietnamese options like Dinosaur exist in the Mission!! :) 
The salads were so refreshing, and came with all the fixins like dried onions, peanuts, fish sauce, etc. The banh mi fillings were well proportioned, and the bread was just the right amount of crispy on the outside but soft on the inside. 
The vibe is young, hip, and it's fun to see it run by some cool, smiley kids :) It's super nice to sit at the wooden tables outside if it's a sunny day and laugh at all the people in line for Ikes, since there is minimal to negligible wait time for a very delicious sandwich at Dinosaur :) 

check into yelp for 10% off entire purchase!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
Sandwich was good, pretty standard for Vietnamese sandwiches, but it was pricey. 

The bread was crispy and it had the essential pickled daikon, carrots, and cilantro. There was a decent amount of meat (I had fancy pork with pate). But $5-$6 for a Vietnamese sandwich is a little expensive. They're usually only around $3-$4 dollars..

I also tried the shrimp and pork spring rolls with peanut hoisin sauce. It was good but also overpriced, It was priced around $6-$7 for 3 spring rolls - definitely not worth $2 per spring roll.

The store itself was very small, it had a few tables inside, but most customers bring their sandwiches to their outdoor seating area to enjoy.

Service was also just okay. Not super friendly, but also not terrible.

There are definitely cheaper and more authentic options out there for Vietnamese sandwiches in SF. Don't know if I'd come back : /
author: Monica T.

description: Didn't really feel like a bánh mì place. They used off the shelf mayonnaise rather the nameless mysterious banh mi sauce. There was no soy sauce/maggi seasoning sprayed on the sandwiches as is traditional. Good if you just want a regular sandwich (at regular sandwich prices, rather than banh mi prices) but I'd really call it banh mi /inspired/ than banh mi.
author: Michael T.

description:
Confession: before I was taken to Dinosaurs, I had never had a Banh Mi sandwich.

I know, Yelp/Californian blasphemy, but I guess since I'd grown out of my nothing-on-my-plate-must-touch and that's-green-are-you-kidding-me-I'm-not-eating-that days, the humble Vietnamese sandwich just never tickled my fancy more than a comforting bowl of pho or a broken rice plate.

That being said, Dinosaurs took my banh mi virginity and took it good. When my friend Kate L. said she was gonna take me to get a sandwich I was daydreaming about a grilled cheese with delicious whole grain bread and some kinda of fancy aioli and then...is that a dinosaur on the window?! COOL! And the little kid that could spell pachycephalosaurus at age 6 came out to play. The little kid liked her sandwich: grilled chicken, carrots, cucumber, really awesome bread, and some mayo (which, in hindsight, I'll probably spike with sriracha next time) made for a delicious pre-dinner that was gobbled in less than 10 minutes.

Extra points for a yelp check-in offer and being vegetarian friendly. I'll be back when I'm in the area!
author: Leslie C.

description:
Had the Crispy Tofu at the 2nd location and the sammy from this location was good as well. 

My coworker had the chicken sandwich which he said was ok.

We also had an order of the pork & shrimp rolls. Great that they allow you to choose which sauce. Instead of boiled pork, they used grilled pork which adds more flavor. 1 order comes w/ 3 rolls which is quite filling. Gave 2 to my other coworker and he loved it.
author: Julie L.

description:
Wow! I never thought that I would find a banh mi place comparable to little Vietnam cafe in the inner richmond!
We came here on a sat evening. We ordered spring rolls, a salmon banh mi and a pork one. Everything was fresh and served fast! 

They have outdoor seating so +1 for being dog friendly!

This place might be my next goto for banh mi!
author: David L.

description: Best Banh Mi place around. Delicious and cheap....can't get any better than this. My favorite has to be the tofu Banh Mi. Also love the lychee watermelon drink. A must try place in San Francisco.
author: Andrew S.

description: The spring rolls here are most excellent.  Gotta head in now for my weekly fix!
author: Dean B.

description: Excellent chicken banh mi. Pleasant counter service.
author: Inigo M.

description: My favorite banh mi in the city!! It's authentic Vietnamese fused with a little San Francisco attitude and flair. I recommend the special or grilled chicken!  Both are STUFFED with lots of meat and pickled veggies on a soft, crisp to the bite baguette. Don't forget to order a watermelon lychee on the side to wash it all down!
author: Alli W.

description: Good sandwiches, reasonably priced, friendly staff. The iced coffee is great! The crispy tofu sandwich is bomb as well. A typical go to for lunch!
author: Carl S.

description:
The first couple times I ever had Banh Mis down at the small Vietnamese baguette places, I could never eat more than 1 1/2 because the bread was too hard and would scratch the roof of my mouth. 

Dinosaurs's bread weren't so dinosaur-like. 

The bread was soft, the Shaking Beef's meat was tender and juicy, and the banh mi was stuffed. Although I don't frequent this area too often, I'd be glad to come back here. There isn't a lot of seating here, so if this place ever has a lot of a people, it might get a little crowded (especially if there were a line). Good thing I came on a rainy day since the place was empty!
author: Jeff Q.

description:
Whether the norm or if it's kosher or not, walking in and out of the window I prefer. It's not so much like hopping into a convertible without opening the doors or ridiculous like coming in through the window from the fire escape like that guy that lived about Martin on the show, Martin, but their 16th street side window that's a step down into their space, and a step up from their floor back onto the sidewalk... yeah, if no one is at that table by the window, I'm using this one. It's charming, and weird, and it makes me want to eat more sandwiches, so I promise fellas... I'll come more often because of that window. 

Most banh mi won't really satisfy me when I am really full and am about to dive into a movie theatre for three hours, but this one did and it was only $5. I really don't know why I'm not eating this $5 and nothing else. Future solo or man date: F train all the way down Market. Dinosaurs. Pilsner Inn patio with said banh mi. Castro theatre. Repeat. (Tip: the Pilsner has $4 pints of fine craft beer & $6 pints of the more rare Napa Smith-styled beers.)

The spicy pork with added paté is dense and traditional, but it's the solid meat to bread ratio that's impressive here, easily 5:3. 

Even if I submit to using the door to come in and out of here, I'll be back.
author: Jon A.

description:
Loved everything we have had there: sandwiches and spring rolls are yummy!

Also great service, friendly staff.
author: Laurent C.

description: Okay, so I am not going to say that this is THE BEST bahn mi in SF (Saigon Sandwich, holla!), BUT it is pretty darn good and open til 10 most nights, while Saigon is only open for lunch. I really like the portobello mushroom bahn mi, which they use vegan mayo in, especially when I add avocado. When they have tofu spring rolls, I like those as well, mainly because, you know, peanut sauce. FYI there tofu for tofu bahn mi and spring rolls are in crispy shreds, not cubes.
author: Ana Y.

description:
The perfect coming home from vacation meal!
You know when you come home from a long trip and youre tired of greasy fast food and you just want some god damned veggies and you want them fast?
This place has fresh ingredients and great service.
author: Molly S.

description:
Ah, Dinosaur, how you always satisfy me:
Fresh, crunchy bread; bright, crisp veggies; flavorful, tender meat...and siracha is the perfect complement.

You have become the banh mi standard that I now compare all banh mi. No, this one's bread is not as good, no that one's meat is chewy and doesn't go as well.  In the end, I'm not satisfied unless it's Dinosaur.  If only you were closer to me...but then I'd probably be there everyday

It's just as well you're so far from me, or I'd be there everyday!
author: Joshua B.

description: OMG!!!!!!!!!!! The shaking beef sandwich is one of the best sandwiches I've ever had!!! Such a good place!! I liked it better than Ike's ! So moist and juicy and the perfect amount of condiments ! Just soooo damn good! Also the coffee there is also very tasty!! But ease do NOT miss out on that shaking beef sandwich !!!!!!!
author: Brianna L.

description: I ordered the special yesterday and yes it was special, lets just say I'm a fan! The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the price, having had many banh mi sandwiches in my lifetime I know it shouldn't cost 8 dollars; but I know the location must have something to do with it and it is SF.
author: Chris T.

description:
Really nice staff and good sandwiches.

I just feel the sandwiches are "Americanized" a bit. They are larger than Saigon Sandwich,  or Little Vietnam, and contain substantially more meat which justifies the price. The flavors lack the boldness of those mentioned above. They are large enough to sometime only eat half. 

Good bread. A lot of I believe lightly pickled carrots, cucumber, cilantro. Feels a pretty healthy option for what is available in the area on the quick (pizza, burger ...pizza, burrito, pizza burger...)

Nice spring rolls and stuff pre-rolled and ready to grab then go.

Very high quality. CONSISTENT quality. Thats hard to do and they do it here seemingly easy. 

This is probably where I would take someone unfamiliar with banh to try it out. The others might even be too bold for some. But personally I like getting kicked in the mouth with flavor the same way I was while in vietnam which none of these truly replicate (could someone PLZ put a fried egg on my banh already???)


So this is a great sandwich place! Come here and order an iced coffee and pork with pate. The coffees are large and not overly sweet. Not as heavy thick as some but a coffee that pleases me. 

I wish they had pho (hint hint) as there is a lack of offerings in the area that are affordable(I'm not paying 12$ at Slurp when at Turtle Towers its 7$ and the best) .

I wish this place great success and hope they expand. Get a little bit more ballsy and unique somehow. This is a very well run business.
author: Peter M.

description:
I come her every so often on my lunch break and Ive got to tell ya...it can be a hit or miss, hence my three star rating.  As far as the sandwiches they are OK, however the bread could be better.  The bread they use is on the hard side and I prefer a softer roll.  Si I stopped ordering the sandwiches and now when I go I just get the spring rolls.  The spring rolls are very good when they are on, but when they are off, the rice wrapper hardens and it feels like you are biting into plastic shrink wrap...and I don't like that.  A friend told me a trick to solve the spring roll problem.  Drop a few droplets of water onto the spring roll and put a paper towel over it and microwave it for 15 seconds or so.  This will re-moisten your spring roll and hopefully solve the problem.  However, when I place my order to eat in their restaurant, I don't have access to a microwave.  They have also raised their prices recently, but that seems to be a trend in this neighborhood.

I do really like their outdoor seating option and is a nice way to catch some SF sun rays while on my lunch break.  Also, Yelp offers a 10% discount for 'checking in' which I'm always sure to take advantage of.
author: Laina R.

description:
Fantastic banh mi, rolls, and snacky snacks.

Everyone who works there is nice and cheerful.

You really can't ask for a better neighborhood sandwich joint. We're lucky to have you, Dinosaurs!

Tip: a nice casual place for dogs (lots of outdoor seating), plus you can pick up flowers at the outdoor florist on Noe & Market afterward.
author: Jessica W.

description: This place is great because you can get a Vietnamese sandwich for a good price and dine in a decent setting. There are outdoor seats. Saigon sandwiches are good and cheap but you are in the middle of tenderloin and there is no seating so its to go only. This place is good cheap and cozy. I had the shaking beef sandwich with double meat. I definitely want to come back and try their chicken or pork. This place is highly suggested though if you are a Vietnamese sandwich junkie.
author: Mario W.

description:
This place's spring rolls deserve 5 stars on their own. If Trader Joe's spring rolls are a 1 out of 10 (blech!), FreshRoll's are a solid 6, then these deserve a 10. I get the tofu and taro rolls with the vegan fish sauce and they are INCREDIBLE. The paper is perfect, the fillings (rice noodles, shredded tofu, taro root, green apple, lettuce, shredded carrots, cilantro, mint) are so, so good, and the sauce is awesome. Can. Not. Possibly. Say. Enough. Good. Things. About. These. Things.

Their tofu banh mi is pretty damn good, too. They are much better than Bun Mee's (which are waywayWAY too greasy). 

The only negative is a minor one: the place is very hot inside, the seats are torn up and tables not always too clean. They could probably use another person cleaning up. But the place is seriously reasonable ($6-7 for three, meal-sized rolls, $5-6 for a banh mi) so they can be forgiven for cutting corners with the ambiance.
author: Jason M.

description:
This is my favorite sandwich place in the castro and I come here often.  I really like the special, spicy tuna, and shaking beef.

So why the two star rating?  I bought a groupon today, $12 for $20 worth of food.  You have to use the entire $20 in one visit.  I bought four sandwiches, but what the groupon didn't say is that the sandwiches are BABY sized!  I'm including pics (links below).  Do not get a groupon, the sandwiches were so tiny i could hold them with just two fingers!!  I feel really cheated, total false advertisement.  One sandwich usually fills me, but I had to eat two groupon-sized sandwiches...totally ridiculous!  

I can't tell whether this is a groupon sandwich or just the new size of all their sandwiches, either way, totally disappointing!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dinosaurs-san-francisco?selected=8F4OYsC1qb76BMdIeWblYg#4cFZNMDSxXY2cetJmhDGjA

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dinosaurs-san-francisco?selected=8F4OYsC1qb76BMdIeWblYg#SI_73uLFt9FQOjCBuv-FbA
author: Kevin M.

description:
It's a little sandwich shop, nothing fancy about the venue (seats about 10 people) but  definitely definitely definitely a well put together sandwich.  They're not skimpy with the toppings.  It's simply great quality!

Sandwiches are about $5...can't go wrong! 

PS the peppers were really spicy to me so I picked them off...but hey if you're into that then that's cool too.
author: Angelica T.

description:
Seriously, I fantasize about their crispy tofu sandwich. It's all crunch & all flavor. French roll...pickled carrots/daikon that aren't overly wilted or tangy...the perfect amount of veganaise...fried, think sticks of tofu & taro...soooo good! I'm not a vegetarian, but most of my meals are meat-free. If you're looking for carne, they've got beef and roasted pork sandwiches the boys in my life  have enjoyed. 

Check in & get 10% off. Five star participant (buy 10, get 1 free.)
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Great sandwiches.  

Dive of a place, so don't expect anything fancy.  Food is consistently very good, which beats fancy restaurants with mediocre food.  Convenient for local take-out grub.

I'd previously gave them 4 stars b/c they substituted substituted medium size shrimps with small shrimps.  They listened to me and others, apparently.   Now, the rolls and the shrimp papaya salad are as fantastic as their beef, chicken, pork, and tofu selections.  Great job, Dinosaurs!  Thanks for taking our feedback into account and keeping us coming back for more!  Thanks for not making us trek far for good food!
author: W G.

description:
